text:
PepsiCo CEO Gets 13% Pay Raise: New Focus Cited By Shoshanna Delventhal | March 21, 2017 — 12:39 PM EDT 
PepsiCo Inc. ( PEP ) has increased the compensation pay of Chief Executive Officer Indra Nooyi by 13%, to $29.8 million in 2016. 
According to a regulatory filing on Friday, the 61-year-old CEO received $14.4 million in cash bonuses and $8.91 million in stock awards last year. Nooyi’s compensation package also included her $1.73 million salary and reflects the fourth consecutive pay raise for the long-serving executive. Consumer Preferences Guide New Focus 
In the most recent fourth quarter, the Purchase, N.Y.-based beverage giant beat the Street’s earnings expectations, attributing stronger-than-expected financials for the quarter to success in a new health focus. PepsiCo now generates about 45% of its revenue from its “guilt-free” product line. (See also: PepsiCo CEO Says Pepsi No Longer a Soda Company .) 
As PepsiCo evolves to meet the demands of a new health-conscious consumer cohort, the firm is also facing pressure from local governments and anti-soda groups hoping to combat obesity, diabetes and surging healthcare costs by weaning consumers off the sugary drinks. 
Along with educational wellness campaigns, many local governments across the nation have imposed heavy taxes on sugary drinks. In India, retailers in southern states have joined together to boycott Pepsi and rival Coca Cola Co. ( KO ) as they attribute depleted ground water resources to the beverage companies’ operations. 
The news of Nooyi’s pay increase comes as the fight against a new local soda tax has escalated in Philadelphia. The Associated Press says an “Ax the Bev Tax” social media campaign has gained significant traction in a measure aimed to squash the new legislation in court or through appeal. While Pepsi and its beverage peers may be fighting back against the new laws, warning that new legislation will force them to cut jobs at home, the leaders have no choice but to follow consumers’ changing preferences through innovation and new health-oriented products. (See also: Beer, Soda Cos. Get in on Sparking Water Trend .)
